trans-unit.source: Specifies which algorithm is used to scale bitmap images.
When animating the scale of any bitmap, the default high-quality image re-sampling algorithm can sometimes consume sufficient system resources to cause frame rate degradation.
This frame rate degradation can cause animations to skip frames or stutter.

By setting the <xref:System.Windows.Media.RenderOptions.BitmapScalingMode%2A> property of the <xref:System.Windows.Media.RenderOptions> object to LowQuality you can create a smoother animation when scaling a bitmap.
Use very high quality Fant bitmap scaling, which is slower than all other bitmap scaling modes, but produces higher quality output.
Use high quality bitmap scaling, which is slower than <xref href="System.Windows.Media.BitmapScalingMode.LowQuality"></xref> mode, but produces higher quality output.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Media.BitmapScalingMode.HighQuality"></xref> mode is the same as the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.BitmapScalingMode.Fant"></xref> mode.
Use linear bitmap scaling, which is faster than <xref href="System.Windows.Media.BitmapScalingMode.HighQuality"></xref> mode, but produces lower quality output.
Use bilinear bitmap scaling, which is faster than <xref href="System.Windows.Media.BitmapScalingMode.HighQuality"></xref> mode, but produces lower quality output.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Media.BitmapScalingMode.LowQuality"></xref> mode is the same as the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.BitmapScalingMode.Linear"></xref> mode.
Use nearest-neighbor bitmap scaling, which provides performance benefits over <xref href="System.Windows.Media.BitmapScalingMode.LowQuality"></xref> mode when the software rasterizer is used.
This mode is often used to magnify a bitmap.
Use the default bitmap scaling mode, which is <xref href="System.Windows.Media.BitmapScalingMode.Linear"></xref>.
